The S&P 500 is paring gains, now down 60 points from its high of the day. (From TKL)
item.content:

The S&P 500 is paring gains, now down 60 points from its high of the day.

item.title:
$TSLA - MUSK'S DOGE DEPARTURE SEEN AS END OF DARK CHAPTER FOR TESLA: WEDBUSH
Elon Musk said on Tesla's latest earnings call that his role in the Trump administration is winding down and that he will be returning his attention to Tesla, a move that allows Musk to turn the corner from a "dark chapter" that accompanied a disastrous quarter for the EV maker, Wedbush analysts Dan Ives and Sam Brandeis say in a research note. They view the call as a turning point in the Tesla story. This was an off-ramp for Tesla to escape the global brand damage, political firestorm and chaos of the past few months, the analysts say. They expect Musk will spend minimal, if any, time with DOGE from here out (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.content:
$TSLA - MUSK'S DOGE DEPARTURE SEEN AS END OF DARK CHAPTER FOR TESLA: WEDBUSH

Elon Musk said on Tesla's latest earnings call that his role in the Trump administration is winding down and that he will be returning his attention to Tesla, a move that allows Musk to turn the corner from a "dark chapter" that accompanied a disastrous quarter for the EV maker, Wedbush analysts Dan Ives and Sam Brandeis say in a research note. They view the call as a turning point in the Tesla story. This was an off-ramp for Tesla to escape the global brand damage, political firestorm and chaos of the past few months, the analysts say. They expect Musk will spend minimal, if any, time with DOGE from here out
item.contentSnippet:

Elon Musk said on Tesla's latest earnings call that his role in the Trump administration is winding down and that he will be returning his attention to Tesla, a move that allows Musk to turn the corner from a "dark chapter" that accompanied a disastrous quarter for the EV maker, Wedbush analysts Dan Ives and Sam Brandeis say in a research note. They view the call as a turning point in the Tesla story. This was an off-ramp for Tesla to escape the global brand damage, political firestorm and chaos of the past few months, the analysts say. They expect Musk will spend minimal, if any, time with DOGE from here out

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at http://www.reventure.app under a premium plan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at reventure.app under a premium plan.
item.contentSnippet: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at reventure.app under a premium plan.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.
But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.
Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.

But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.

Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening.
item.contentSnippet:
6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.
But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.
Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.
In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.
Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.

In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.

Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city.
item.contentSnippet:
5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.
In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.
Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).
The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.
Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years). (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).

The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.

Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years).
item.contentSnippet:
4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).
The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.
Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years).

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.
However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.

However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms.
item.contentSnippet:
3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.
However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.
Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.
Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.
The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.

Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.

Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.

The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued.
item.contentSnippet:
2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.
Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.
Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.
The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.
But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.
For instance, take a look at Manhattan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.

But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.

For instance, take a look at Manhattan.
item.contentSnippet:
1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.
But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.
For instance, take a look at Manhattan.

item.title:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.
Manhattan - 25% undervalued Bronx - 22% DC - 18% New Orelans - 11% San Francisco- 11% Queens - 5% Brooklyn - 4% Chicago - 3% Boston - 2%
All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.
Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.

Manhattan - 25% undervalued
Bronx - 22%
DC - 18%
New Orelans - 11%
San Francisco- 11%
Queens - 5%
Brooklyn - 4%
Chicago - 3%
Boston - 2%

All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.

Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades.
item.contentSnippet:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.
Manhattan - 25% undervalued Bronx - 22% DC - 18% New Orelans - 11% San Francisco- 11% Queens - 5% Brooklyn - 4% Chicago - 3% Boston - 2%
All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.
Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades.

item.title:
Keep watching the U.S. Dollar:
As the S&P 500 rises +5% in 2 days on ‚Äútariff de-escalation‚Äù headlines, the U.S. Dollar Index, $DXY, is up a mere 0.2% today.
The U.S. Dollar is just about the only asset not buying these headlines today.
Furthermore, the U.S. Dollar has been a key leading indicator of trade war sentiment.
It‚Äôs almost as though the U.S. Dollar thinks U.S. trade headlines have lost credibility.
Something is off. (From TKL)
item.content:

The U.S. Dollar is just about the only asset not buying these headlines today.

Furthermore, the U.S. Dollar has been a key leading indicator of trade war sentiment.

It‚Äôs almost as though the U.S. Dollar thinks U.S. trade headlines have lost credibility.

item.title:
Retail investors were just cheated:
Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."
These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.
This summit was not open to the public or to the media.
Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."
Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.
The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.
Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.
How is this fair for retail investors? (From TKL)
item.content:
Retail investors were just cheated:

Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."

These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.

This summit was not open to the public or to the media.

Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."

Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.

The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.

Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.

How is this fair for retail investors?
item.contentSnippet:
Retail investors were just cheated:
Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."
These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.
This summit was not open to the public or to the media.
Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."
Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.
The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.
Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.
How is this fair for retail investors?

item.title:
Something doesn't add up here:
1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"
2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell
3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"
4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell
5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"
6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell
What changed today? (From TKL)
item.content:
Something doesn't add up here:

1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"

2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell

3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"

4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell

5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"

6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell

What changed today?
item.contentSnippet:
Something doesn't add up here:
1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"
2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell
3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"
4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell
5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"
6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell
What changed today?

item.title:

Moreover, Manhattan's housing market was also struggling prior to the pandemic.
So in terms of relative affordability, it has gained significantly. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)

item.title:
Typical home (condo/co-op) value in Manhattan today is $1.1 million.
Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.
The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.
Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
Typical home (condo/co-op) value in Manhattan today is $1.1 million.

Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.

The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.

Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now.
item.contentSnippet:

Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.
The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.
Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now.

item.content:
Today on The Big Picture on Market On Close:

‚Äî¬†@LizAnnSonders says that "any move by the Fed to preemptively start easing policy aggressively ... might not have the intended effect of boosting growth or boosting confidence."

‚Äî¬†Cooper Howard tells @Cline_Woods that "the market is concerned about the independence of the Fed."

‚Äî¬†Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession.

item.title: RT by @Barchart: NEWSLETTER: Something very weird is happening. (From Barchart)

item.title:
#Earnings get heavy this week. With 12% of S&P 500 companies reporting results, 71% have beaten analysts' earnings per share estimates and 61% have reported a positive revenue surprise. Economic reports include March new home sales, the Fed's Beige Book on economic conditions around the country, and final April consumer sentiment.
For more on the week ahead: üì∞ Read the latest Schwab Market Update ‚û°Ô∏èhttps://www.schwab.com/learn/story/stock-market-update-open
üé• Watch @JeffreyKleintop 90-second Weekly Market Outlook video ‚§µÔ∏è (From SchwabR)

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 7) In the meantime, Reventure still expects prices to drop. We have Austin tabbed as a 32/100 on our price forecast score, which corresponds to -6.3% contraction over next 12 months.
To access our price forecast for your area, head to http://www.reventure.app and sign up for a premium plan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
7) In the meantime, Reventure still expects prices to drop. We have Austin tabbed as a 32/100 on our price forecast score, which corresponds to -6.3% contraction over next 12 months.

To access our price forecast for your area, head to reventure.app and sign up for a premium plan.
